lens.lens_summary: A traditional landlord with immediate-payment expectations and limited English proficiency reveals where Split Lease's assumptions about host mental models are most dangerously untested, demanding hypothesis-driven validation of every trust and payment comprehension moment in the host journey.

discovery.what_this_lens_reveals: Robbie did not discover Split Lease through the platform. He discovered it because two prospective guests (Ariel and Amber) were matched by a Split Lease agent and the agent reached out to him as the property owner. His Craigslist listing was already removed at the time of the call, meaning he had already exhausted one discovery channel. The Lean UX lens exposes a critical untested assumption: that hosts arrive at Split Lease through the platform's own discovery channels. Robbie's case shows the opposite — the platform discovered HIM, via agent outreach anchored to a now-defunct third-party listing. The platform's assumption about how hosts find it must be stated as a hypothesis and tested: 'We believe hosts will discover Split Lease through our website/marketing. We will know this is true when we see X% of signups originating from organic or paid acquisition.' Robbie's case would invalidate that hypothesis — he was acquired through manual agent prospecting on Craigslist.

user_state.emotional_state: Receptive but transactional — Robbie is open to the call because he is 'receiving so many people' interested in his space (00:03), indicating demand pressure. He is not curious about the platform; he wants to fill his unit.
user_state.knowledge_level: Zero knowledge of Split Lease as a concept or platform. He has never heard of the payment guarantee model, the dual-agreement structure, or the agent-mediated matching process. His mental model is Craigslist: post, receive inquiries, collect payment directly.
user_state.commitment_level: Low — he is listening because someone called him, not because he sought out the service. He has not invested any effort yet.
user_state.data_available: Craigslist listing (now removed), property address (East Village studio), monthly rent ($1,600), photos exist but need to be re-shared via a new link.

reasons: His Craigslist listing was removed, so the original discovery artifact is gone — any follow-up that references it will hit a dead end
He was contacted by the agent, not the other way around, so his intrinsic motivation to explore the platform is low
He is receiving 'so many' inquiries, meaning he has alternatives and Split Lease must compete for his attention
dropout_risk.evidence: robbie-call.txt, 00:03: 'we are receiving so many, uh, people getting these profits I've been trying to call you then' and 01:00: 'the Craigslist link looked like it had been removed or is no longer active'

key_quotes.quote: I just want to know, because we are receiving so many, uh, people getting these profits I've been trying to call you then.
key_quotes.relevance: Reveals Robbie's discovery state: he is in demand, fielding multiple inquiries. Split Lease is one of many suitors, not a unique discovery. The Lean UX principle of continuous discovery applies here — the platform must continuously learn which acquisition paths actually convert landlords like Robbie.

key_quotes.quote: Every project starts with assumptions, but usually we don't explicitly acknowledge this fact. Instead, we try to ignore assumptions, or worse, treat them as facts.
key_quotes.relevance: The assumption that hosts discover Split Lease through the platform's own channels is exactly this kind of hidden assumption. Robbie's case proves it must be stated and tested, not treated as fact.

evaluation.what_this_lens_reveals: Robbie's evaluation is entirely mediated by the phone call with Bryant — he has no independent frame of reference for Split Lease. The Lean UX lens reveals that the call itself is an MVP (minimum viable product) for the evaluation phase: it is the smallest thing the company can build to test whether a traditional landlord will understand and accept the Split Lease model. Robbie's call reveals that this MVP is partially failing. He does not understand the payment flow after a 7-minute explanation. He repeatedly asks about immediate payment confirmation and contract signing, indicating that Bryant's explanation did not bridge the gap between Robbie's mental model (immediate payment upon contract) and Split Lease's model (payment released after first night of booking). This is exactly the kind of assumption that Lean UX demands be tested: 'We believe that a phone call explanation of the payment model will achieve host comprehension. We will know this is true when the host does not re-ask about payment timing after the initial explanation.' Robbie's call invalidates this hypothesis — he re-asks at 03:17, 04:06, and 06:00.

user_state.emotional_state: Cautious and increasingly confused — Robbie's repeated returns to the payment question (03:17, 04:06, 06:00) show that he is not satisfied with the explanation. His language becomes more emphatic ('we have to confirm the payment immediately,' 'the contract has been fueled') as he tries to assert his own mental model against the one being presented.
user_state.knowledge_level: Partial and conflicting — he has heard the words 'payment guarantee' and 'rental agreement' but has mapped them onto his existing landlord schema (payment confirmed immediately, contract signed before reservation). The Split Lease model (payment after first night, dual agreements) does not fit his schema and he cannot reconcile the two.
user_state.commitment_level: Conditional — he is willing to look at the agreements ('just send it to me and let me see,' 07:10) but has not committed to anything. His commitment is gated on reading the documents himself.
user_state.data_available: Verbal explanation of payment flow, mention of dual agreements (rental + supplemental), security deposit matching ($3,200), names of prospective guests (Ariel and Amber).

reasons: Fundamental comprehension gap on payment timing — Robbie expects immediate payment upon contract, Split Lease releases payment after first night of booking
Language barrier compounds the comprehension gap — Robbie is a non-native English speaker processing complex financial terms
No visual aid during the call — the entire payment model is explained verbally with no diagram, timeline, or document to anchor understanding
Robbie's existing mental model (traditional landlord: contract → immediate payment → occupancy) directly conflicts with Split Lease's model (contract → occupancy → payment release)
dropout_risk.evidence: robbie-call.txt, 04:06: 'this me, where this have to be confirmed immediately. You feel the contract phone to, uh, to, to hold any property for you out loss' and 06:14: 'we have to confirm the payment immediately. The contract has been fueled. I was saying to me, you'll have to make the payment immediately.'

key_quotes.quote: I understand your explanation, but it goes this way. We have to confirm the payment immediately. The contract has been fueled.
key_quotes.relevance: This is the clearest evidence of a failed hypothesis. Robbie explicitly says he understands the explanation but then reasserts his own contradictory model. In Lean UX terms, the MVP (verbal explanation) has been tested and produced negative market feedback: the host restates the incorrect assumption even after correction.

key_quotes.quote: We believe [this statement is true]. We will know we're [right/wrong] when we see the following feedback from the market.
key_quotes.relevance: The hypothesis 'We believe a verbal explanation of delayed payment release will be understood by traditional landlords' is invalidated by Robbie's repeated re-asking. The market feedback (host restating incorrect model 3 times) is the qualitative signal that this hypothesis has failed.

key_quotes.quote: We'd hold the security deposit as well. And we'd actually matched that. So rather than holding 1600, we'd hold 3,200.
key_quotes.relevance: The security deposit match is introduced as a trust-building feature, but Robbie does not respond to it. In Lean UX terms, this feature's value proposition was not validated — there is no market feedback signal that the host perceives the double deposit as a benefit.

onboarding.what_this_lens_reveals: Robbie's onboarding has not yet occurred at the time of the call, but the call reveals exactly what he will need to see to proceed. He wants to receive the agreement documents by email, review them on his own time, and then decide. The Lean UX lens exposes the onboarding hypothesis: 'We believe that sending agreement examples via email will be sufficient to convert an evaluated host into an onboarded one.' Robbie's case tests this hypothesis under adversarial conditions — a host who did not understand the payment model verbally, who expects immediate payment upon contract, and who processes agreements in a language that is not his first. The onboarding materials must function as a standalone MVP that succeeds where the verbal explanation failed. If the documents use the same language and structure as the call, they will produce the same comprehension failure.

user_state.emotional_state: Guarded but not hostile — Robbie ends the call saying 'send it to me and let me see' (07:10), indicating willingness to evaluate but not willingness to commit without independent review.
user_state.knowledge_level: Knows that two agreements exist (rental + supplemental) but does not understand the content or purpose of either. Does not understand why payment is not immediate upon contract signing.
user_state.commitment_level: Pre-commitment — he has agreed only to receive and review documents, not to sign or proceed. This is the lowest meaningful commitment level.
user_state.data_available: His email address (to be shared), Bryant's contact info, names of prospective guests, rent amount ($1,600), security deposit structure ($3,200).

reasons: The onboarding materials must succeed where the verbal explanation failed — if they use the same framing, the same comprehension gap will persist
Robbie is a non-native English speaker who will be reading legal-style agreement documents independently, without Bryant available to clarify
He has a fundamentally incorrect mental model of the payment flow that the documents must correct, not just inform
Time decay: the longer between the call and the document review, the weaker the relationship. There is no indication of urgency on Robbie's side
dropout_risk.evidence: robbie-call.txt, 07:10: 'Oh, they didn't know what, uh, how many, something of the agreement you're talking about. Um, just send it to me and let me see' — Robbie does not even know how many agreements there are or what they contain, despite a 7-minute explanation.

key_quotes.quote: Oh, they didn't know what, uh, how many, something of the agreement you're talking about. Um, just send it to me and let me see, I'll send you my PMO.
key_quotes.relevance: After a full call, Robbie does not know what documents he will receive. In Lean UX terms, the shared understanding that the Lean UX framework demands between team and customer has not been achieved. The onboarding must build this understanding from scratch.

key_quotes.quote: Shared understanding is the collective knowledge of the team that builds up over time as the team works together. It's a rich understanding of the space, the product, and the customers.
key_quotes.relevance: The call failed to create shared understanding between Bryant and Robbie about what the agreements are and how payment works. Onboarding materials must function as a new attempt to build this shared understanding, not merely repeat the failed attempt.

listing_creation.what_this_lens_reveals: Robbie's listing already existed on Craigslist but has been removed. He has photos, a rent price, and an address. The Lean UX lens frames listing creation as a hypothesis: 'We believe that a 6-step wizard will enable hosts to create high-quality listings. We will know this is true when wizard completion rate exceeds 75%.' Robbie's case challenges this hypothesis from a specific angle: he has already done the work of creating a listing elsewhere. Asking him to redo it on Split Lease is waste — it provides no value to the host and consumes his depleted cognitive resources. The Lean UX principle of removing waste demands: if the host has already created a listing on another platform, the Split Lease listing creation process should import or reference that work, not ignore it. Furthermore, Robbie's listing was created for a fundamentally different model (traditional monthly rental) and will need translation to Split Lease's model (nights-of-the-week, per-night pricing). This translation is itself an untested assumption.

user_state.emotional_state: Impatient — Robbie already did this work on Craigslist and now must redo it. He offers to send the link (01:42, 02:49) rather than describe the space verbally, indicating he wants to reuse his existing work, not start over.
user_state.knowledge_level: Expert on his own property but novice on Split Lease's listing format. He knows his space (renovated large studio, East Village, $1,600/month) but does not know how Split Lease categorizes spaces, what information is needed, or how per-night pricing maps to his monthly rent expectation.
user_state.commitment_level: Not yet reached this phase — listing creation is gated behind onboarding, which is gated behind document review.
user_state.data_available: Photos (existing but link broken), property description (from removed Craigslist ad), address (East Village), monthly rent ($1,600), space type (renovated large studio).

reasons: Host has already created a listing elsewhere and perceives re-creation as redundant effort
Translation from monthly rent ($1,600) to per-night pricing requires a mental model shift that has not been prepared for
The 6-step wizard (Space Snapshot, Features, Lease Styles, Pricing, Rules, Photos) is designed for hosts who arrive ready to create from scratch — Robbie arrives with existing assets and expectations
Non-native English speaker navigating a multi-step form with unfamiliar terminology (e.g., 'Lease Styles: Nights-of-the-week')
dropout_risk.evidence: robbie-call.txt, 01:42: 'I will send you, uh, probably so I can forward you that link. I lost where the pictures' and 02:49: 'I was sending the address on everything on the link. I'm going to send you the link of the app' — Robbie assumes his existing listing can be reused and redirects to it repeatedly.

key_quotes.quote: I will send you, uh, probably so I can forward you that link. I lost where the pictures.
key_quotes.relevance: Robbie's instinct is to reuse his existing listing, not create a new one. In Lean UX terms, the platform's listing creation process has an untested assumption: that hosts will willingly recreate what they have already built. The Lean UX principle of removing waste suggests the platform should accept existing listings as input.

key_quotes.quote: Anything that doesn't contribute to [improved outcomes] is considered waste and should be removed from the team's process.
key_quotes.relevance: Forcing Robbie to recreate a listing he already made on Craigslist is pure waste from the host's perspective. The outcome (a published listing) could be achieved faster by importing or adapting his existing work.

pricing.what_this_lens_reveals: Robbie's pricing mental model is simple and fixed: $1,600/month. He states it as a fact (02:22). The Split Lease model requires translating this into per-night pricing for a nights-of-the-week lease style. This translation is a critical untested assumption. The Lean UX hypothesis: 'We believe that hosts who think in monthly terms can successfully set per-night pricing through the wizard. We will know this is true when hosts set prices that, when calculated over a month, approximate their stated monthly rent.' Robbie's case is a stress test for this hypothesis because: (1) he has never thought about his space in per-night terms, (2) the math is non-trivial ($1,600/month ÷ how many nights per week × 4 weeks), and (3) he is a non-native English speaker processing unfamiliar financial structures. Additionally, Bryant explains the payment flow as '$1,600 would be released to you after that first night' (05:03-05:37), which anchors Robbie to $1,600 as a lump sum — not as a result of per-night calculations. The pricing wizard must bridge this gap or Robbie will either set the wrong price or abandon.

user_state.emotional_state: Anchored and inflexible — Robbie has stated '$1,600 a month' as his price and expects to receive exactly that. Any pricing interface that makes him feel like he might receive a different amount will trigger resistance.
user_state.knowledge_level: Knows his monthly rent target but does not understand how Split Lease's per-night pricing maps to his monthly expectation. Does not understand the fee structure or how Split Lease's cut affects his take-home.
user_state.commitment_level: Not yet reached this phase — but his pricing commitment is already set at $1,600/month regardless of what the platform interface shows.
user_state.data_available: Monthly rent: $1,600, security deposit: $1,600 (matched to $3,200 by Split Lease).

reasons: The monthly-to-nightly price translation is non-trivial and has not been prepared for in the call
Any display of a nightly rate that, when multiplied out, does not approximate $1,600/month will trigger distrust
The Split Lease fee structure has not been explained — Robbie does not know what percentage Split Lease takes, so he cannot verify his take-home
The pricing wizard uses 'default values already populated' (per journey map), but if these defaults do not match $1,600/month, Robbie may reject them or accept incorrect defaults
dropout_risk.evidence: robbie-call.txt, 02:22: 'it sounded like it's 16, 1600 a month would be the monthly rent' — this is Robbie's anchor. Everything in the pricing phase must validate against this anchor or the host will perceive a discrepancy.

key_quotes.quote: It sounded like it's 16, 1600 a month would be the monthly rent.
key_quotes.relevance: Robbie's pricing anchor. In Lean UX terms, this is the outcome the host expects. The pricing interface must make the connection between per-night rate and monthly income explicit and immediate, or the host will perceive a mismatch.

key_quotes.quote: When you're creating hypotheses to test, you want to try to be very specific regarding the outcomes you are trying to achieve.
key_quotes.relevance: The pricing phase outcome is not 'host sets a nightly rate' — it is 'host sees that the nightly rate produces their expected monthly income.' The distinction between output (nightly rate field filled) and outcome (host confident they will receive $1,600/month) is exactly what Lean UX demands.

proposal_mgmt.what_this_lens_reveals: In Robbie's case, proposal management is inverted: the guests (Ariel and Amber) were matched to his property by Bryant before Robbie even joined the platform. There is no discovery-browse-propose sequence from the guest side. The proposal is pre-arranged. The Lean UX lens reveals a hidden assumption: 'We believe the proposal flow works the same way whether the guest discovered the listing organically or was matched by an agent.' Robbie's case tests this assumption. He expects the guests to 'make the payment' (03:17, 05:03) as a condition of the proposal, not as a consequence of acceptance. His mental model is: contract → payment → occupancy. The platform's model is: proposal → acceptance → documents → first night → payment release. These are structurally incompatible sequences. The proposal management interface must either educate Robbie on the platform's sequence or accommodate his expectation — and which approach to take is itself a hypothesis that must be tested.

user_state.emotional_state: Controlling — Robbie wants confirmation of payment before he agrees to hold the property. He uses language of obligation ('you'll have to make the payment immediately,' 06:14) and risk ('to hold any property for you out loss,' 04:06). He perceives delay between contract and payment as a risk of financial loss.
user_state.knowledge_level: Knows that Ariel and Amber are the prospective guests but does not understand the proposal-counter-accept flow. Does not know he will need to review terms on the platform, modify duration, or confirm digitally.
user_state.commitment_level: Conditional on payment confirmation — he will not proceed unless he believes payment is secured. This is the hardest commitment gate in his journey.
user_state.data_available: Guest names (Ariel and Amber), rent amount ($1,600), security deposit ($3,200 total), payment guarantee mentioned but not understood.

reasons: Robbie's mental model requires payment confirmation before holding the property — the platform's flow provides payment release after the first night of occupancy
He has explicitly stated his requirement three times during the call (03:17, 04:06, 06:14), each time more forcefully, and each time Bryant has redirected rather than resolved
Bryant's explanation of pre-authorized credit card charges (06:37) partially addresses this but uses financial terminology ('pre-authorized') that may not translate for a non-native speaker
The proposal management interface will present terms for review and modification, but Robbie's primary concern (payment timing) is not a modifiable term — it is a platform policy he must accept
dropout_risk.evidence: robbie-call.txt, 06:37: 'the payment would be collected beforehand and the charges are pre-authorized on the credit card, which is why there's the guarantee' — Bryant attempts to resolve the payment timing concern but Robbie's next action (07:10) is to ask for the documents, indicating the verbal explanation did not resolve the concern.

key_quotes.quote: This me, where this have to be confirmed immediately. You feel the contract phone to, uh, to, to hold any property for you out loss.
key_quotes.relevance: Robbie articulates his core risk: holding a property without confirmed payment means potential financial loss. This is the assumption the platform must validate or address — 'We believe hosts will accept delayed payment release because of the guarantee. We will know we're wrong when hosts refuse to proceed without upfront payment confirmation.'

key_quotes.quote: Permission to fail means that the team has a safe environment in which to experiment.
key_quotes.relevance: The platform cannot ask Robbie to 'fail forward' — he perceives financial loss, not learning opportunity. The Lean UX team, however, must use permission to fail internally: test multiple versions of the payment explanation and proposal flow to find one that converts traditional landlords.

active_lease.what_this_lens_reveals: The Robbie call does not reach the active lease phase, but the Lean UX lens combined with his behavioral patterns reveals what will matter most. Robbie is a host who demands immediate payment confirmation and explicit contractual clarity. During an active lease, payments are released on a monthly schedule after the first night of each month. Every payment release is a moment where Robbie's hypothesis ('I will receive $1,600 on time') is either validated or invalidated. The Lean UX framework treats each of these as an experiment outcome. The Stays Manager and Leases page must function as a continuous feedback mechanism — not just showing that payment was released, but showing that it was released on time, for the correct amount, and that the next payment is already pre-authorized. For a host like Robbie, the absence of this feedback will be interpreted as evidence that the system is not working, even if payments are flowing correctly behind the scenes.

user_state.emotional_state: Projected: vigilant and verification-seeking — based on his call behavior, Robbie will actively check payment status and will interpret any delay or ambiguity as a problem.
user_state.knowledge_level: Will need to learn the Leases page, Stays Manager, Date Change Tool, and review system — all entirely new concepts not mentioned in the call.
user_state.commitment_level: Conditional on each payment release — commitment is renewed monthly, not once. Each late or unclear payment risks de-commitment.
user_state.data_available: Active lease terms, payment schedule, guest identity, stay dates.

reasons: Payment release timing is the single most important signal for Robbie — any delay or lack of transparency will trigger the same concerns he raised during the evaluation call
He has no existing relationship with the platform's active lease tools — every interaction will be a first-time experience
The Date Change Tool and stay review system are entirely unmentioned in the call, meaning Robbie will encounter them without any preparation or mental model
dropout_risk.evidence: robbie-call.txt, 03:25-03:33 (Bryant's explanation): 'the first payment or the payment for the first 30 nights would be given to you after the first night of the booking' — this is the only preparation Robbie has for active lease payment timing. Every deviation from this exact promise will be noticed.

key_quotes.quote: Even in the case that Ariel or Amber would miss a payment, you're still getting payment for the booking.
key_quotes.relevance: The payment guarantee is the core value proposition during the active lease phase. For Robbie, the Leases page must continuously validate this guarantee — not just state it once, but prove it every month through visible, timely payment releases.

key_quotes.quote: Continuous discovery is the ongoing process of engaging the customer during the design and development process... The goal is to understand what the users are doing with your products and why they are doing it.
key_quotes.relevance: During the active lease, continuous discovery means monitoring whether hosts like Robbie are checking payment status, how often, and whether they contact support about payment concerns. This behavioral data is the market feedback that validates or invalidates the Leases page design.

retention.what_this_lens_reveals: Robbie's retention will be entirely outcome-driven: did he receive $1,600/month on time, every month, without complications? The Lean UX lens frames retention as the ultimate hypothesis test: 'We believe that hosts who complete a successful lease will list again. We will know this is true when X% of hosts create a second listing within 30 days of lease completion.' For Robbie, however, the retention hypothesis has a prerequisite: the definition of 'successful' must match his definition, not the platform's. If payments were on time but required him to check repeatedly, contact support, or experience anxiety about timing, his subjective experience of the lease is 'stressful' even if the objective outcome (payments delivered) was achieved. The Lean UX distinction between output (payment delivered) and outcome (host felt confident and secure throughout) applies directly here. Retention is predicted by the outcome, not the output.

user_state.emotional_state: Projected: evaluative — comparing the Split Lease experience against his baseline expectation (Craigslist: find tenant, collect rent, no intermediary). If Split Lease was harder or more stressful than Craigslist, he will not return.
user_state.knowledge_level: By this point, high on his specific lease but still potentially low on the platform's broader capabilities (e.g., he may not know he can list multiple properties, adjust pricing, or use the referral system).
user_state.commitment_level: Outcome-dependent — if the first lease was a positive experience (defined by Robbie's criteria: timely payment, no surprises, no hassle), commitment to a second listing is likely. If not, he returns to Craigslist.
user_state.data_available: Complete lease history, payment records, guest reviews, stay completion data.

reasons: Robbie has an existing alternative (Craigslist) that, while less sophisticated, matches his mental model of how renting works
His retention will be compared against the Craigslist baseline: simpler, no intermediary, immediate payment
Any friction during the active lease (payment timing confusion, unfamiliar tools, support interactions) accumulates and reduces retention probability
The platform has not yet established any retention-specific features mentioned in the call — no referral program, no multi-listing discount, no re-listing shortcut
dropout_risk.evidence: robbie-call.txt, 00:03 and KEY BEHAVIORAL OBSERVATIONS: Robbie is receiving many inquiries through other channels. He does not need Split Lease — Split Lease needs him. Retention requires proving that the platform is superior to his existing alternatives, not just equivalent.

key_quotes.source: leanux-hypothesis-driven-design.txt, Ch 2 Progress = Outcomes, Not Output
key_quotes.quote: Features and services are outputs. The business goals they are meant to achieve are outcomes. Lean UX measures progress in terms of explicitly defined business outcomes.
key_quotes.relevance: Retention is the outcome. Payment processing, lease management, and stay tracking are all outputs. Measuring retention by whether the platform delivered payments correctly (output) misses whether the host felt secure and served (outcome). Robbie's retention depends on the outcome, not the output.

key_quotes.quote: We are receiving so many, uh, people getting these profits.
key_quotes.relevance: Robbie has alternatives. Retention is not guaranteed by a single successful lease — it requires the platform to be demonstrably better than his other channels across his full evaluation criteria (payment timing, hassle level, reliability).

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: Payment comprehension gap persists across phases and will compound if not resolved at evaluation
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Robbie re-asks about payment timing 3 times during the call (03:17, 04:06, 06:14), each time more forcefully. Bryant provides increasingly detailed explanations but does not confirm that Robbie understands. The Lean UX framework (Ch 3, Hypotheses) demands treating this as a failed hypothesis: 'We believe verbal explanation of delayed payment release will achieve host comprehension.' The market feedback (3 re-asks) invalidates it. If this gap is not closed at onboarding (when documents are reviewed), it will compound at pricing (where per-night rates feel disconnected from monthly income), at proposal management (where payment is not immediate upon acceptance), at active lease (where payment releases on a schedule, not on demand), and at retention (where the cumulative anxiety of unclear payment timing drives the host back to Craigslist's simpler model).

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: Host's existing mental model (traditional landlord) conflicts with platform model at every phase, requiring systematic hypothesis testing rather than one-time education
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Robbie's mental model is: post listing → receive inquiries → contract → immediate payment → tenant moves in. Split Lease's model is: agent matches guests → host is contacted → evaluation call → documents sent → host onboards → listing created → per-night pricing set → proposal received → terms negotiated → acceptance → documents signed → first night → payment released. Every phase transition introduces a new point of conflict between these models. The Lean UX Business Assumptions Worksheet (Ch 3) asks: 'My biggest product risk is ___.' For hosts like Robbie, the biggest risk is that the platform's model is so different from the host's expectation that comprehension fails before conversion. This is not a UI problem — it is a model-translation problem that requires hypothesis testing at each transition: 'We believe [this explanation/interface/document] will bridge the gap between the traditional landlord model and the Split Lease model at [this specific transition].'

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: Language barrier amplifies every other friction point — a multiplier effect on dropout risk across all phases
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Robbie is a non-native English speaker (KEY BEHAVIORAL OBSERVATIONS). His language difficulties are visible at 04:06 ('this me, where this have to be confirmed immediately. You feel the contract phone to, uh, to, to hold any property for you out loss'), 06:14 ('The contract has been fueled'), and 07:10 ('how many, something of the agreement you're talking about'). Each of these shows comprehension difficulty, not just expression difficulty. The Lean UX principle of continuous discovery (Ch 2) demands understanding not just what users do but why they do it. For Robbie, language difficulty is a hidden 'why' behind potential abandonment at every phase. A host who does not fully understand the words on the screen will not complete a 6-step wizard, set correct pricing, or review a proposal with confidence. The platform's untested assumption is that all hosts are fluent in English — this is a hypothesis that Robbie's case invalidates.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: The agent-mediated acquisition path creates expectations the self-service platform cannot meet without deliberate design bridging
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Robbie was discovered by Bryant, explained to by Bryant, and promised follow-up by Bryant. His experience of Split Lease is 100% human-mediated. The platform is 100% self-service. The Lean UX principle of shared understanding (Ch 2) requires that the team and the customer have a common understanding. But Robbie's shared understanding is with Bryant (a person), not with the platform (a product). When he encounters the platform for the first time, there is no shared understanding — he must build it from scratch, alone, in a second language. The Lean UX MVP concept (Ch 5) suggests the smallest thing you can build to bridge this gap: a landing page personalized with Bryant's name, Robbie's property details, and the specific terms discussed in the call. This MVP tests the hypothesis: 'We believe a personalized post-call landing page will reduce the human-to-digital trust gap.'

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: Robbie's demand for immediate payment confirmation is an outcome-focused behavior that the platform must measure, not suppress
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: The Lean UX principle 'Progress = Outcomes, Not Output' (Ch 2) states that features are outputs while the business goals they achieve are outcomes. Robbie's repeated demand for immediate payment confirmation (03:17, 04:06, 06:14) is not a complaint about a feature — it is an articulation of his desired outcome: certainty that he will be paid. The platform's response should not be to add a feature (e.g., a payment confirmation button) but to achieve the outcome (host feels certain of payment). This distinction applies across phases: at evaluation (does he believe payment is guaranteed?), at proposal management (does accepting a proposal feel like securing payment?), at active lease (does each payment release reinforce confidence?), and at retention (does the cumulative experience of reliable payment create loyalty?). Measuring payment confirmation anxiety — how often hosts check payment status, how often they contact support about payments, how many calls reference payment timing — is the continuous discovery mechanism for this outcome.

sources_consulted: Agents-data-source/Books/extracts/leanux-hypothesis-driven-design.txt (Chapters 1-5: Why Lean UX, Principles, Vision/Framing/Outcomes, Collaborative Design, MVPs and Experiments)
library/elements.json (first 200 lines — schema and existing element patterns)
